questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a protruding mass from her vagina and difficulty urinating. Physical examination reveals third-degree uterine prolapse with an ulcerated area on the prolapsed tissue as shown in the image. Which of the following correctly describes the cause of the ulcerated area and the appropriate management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Ulcer occurs due to infection; management includes antibiotics and surgical intervention.

options.label: B
options.text: Ulcer occurs due to repeated friction; management includes local wound care and topical corticosteroids.

options.label: C
options.text: Ulcer occurs due to allergic reactions; management includes antihistaminics and surgical intervention.

options.label: D
options.text: Ulcer occurs due to venous congestion; management includes antiseptic and hygroscopic packing.

questions.correct_answer: D. Ulcer occurs due to venous congestion; management includes antiseptic and hygroscopic packing.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the usage of pessary in a prolapse patient except?

options.label: A
options.text: Are a non-surgical option for managing pelvic organ prolapse.

options.label: B
options.text: Can be used as a temporary measure before surgical intervention.

options.label: C
options.text: Regular follow-up is not required once a pessary is adequately fitted.

options.label: D
options.text: Pessaries can be used to treat stress urinary incontinence.

questions.correct_answer: C. Regular follow-up is not required once a pessary is adequately fitted.
questions.explanation:
Types

Ring Pessary, Gellhorn Pessary, Donut Pessary.

Mechanism
  • Provides mechanical support to the pelvic organs
  • Helps with urinary and bowel symptoms

Conditions
  • Patients with complications (stress urinary incontinence, combined prolapse) (Option D)
  • Non-surgical management for inoperable cases (Option A)
  • Patients awaiting surgery (temporary relief) (Option B)
  • Prolapse in a pregnant female.

Disadvantages
  • Vaginal irritation, discharge, infection.
  • Pressure necrosis
  • Regular follow-up (Option C)

Contraindications
  • Active pelvic infection
  • Allergic reaction to material
  • Non-compliance with follow-up

questions.text: A 34-year-old reproductive-age female presents with significant uterine prolapse and expresses concerns about future childbearing. Which surgical management option is most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation:
Dynamic Sling
  • Uses materials allowing for some movement and flexibility.
  • Eg: Purandare sling

Static Sling
  • Utilizes non-flexible materials providing rigid support.
  • Eg:Shirodkar sling and Khanna sling

Composite
  • Combines elements of both dynamic and static slings
  • Eg: Virkud sling

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a sensation of a bulge in her vaginal area, which worsens on straining. On examination, a protrusion of the vaginal apex beyond the hymen is noted. There is no associated urinary incontinence. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Treatment Option Indications
  • ↳ Treatment Option
  • ↳ Treatment Option
  • ↳ Treatment Option
  • ↳ Indications
  • ↳ Indications
  • ↳ Indications
  • ↳ Conservative (pelvic floor exercises) (Option A) Mild prolapse, asymptomatic, patient preference
  • ↳ Conservative (pelvic floor exercises) (Option A)
  • ↳ Conservative (pelvic floor exercises) (Option A)
  • ↳ (Option A)
  • ↳ Mild prolapse, asymptomatic, patient preference
  • ↳ Mild prolapse, asymptomatic, patient preference
  • ↳ Pessary fitting (Option B) Symptomatic prolapse, desire for non-surgical management in mild to moderate cases.
  • ↳ Pessary fitting (Option B)
  • ↳ Pessary fitting (Option B)
  • ↳ (Option B)
  • ↳ Symptomatic prolapse, desire for non-surgical management in mild to moderate cases.
  • ↳ Symptomatic prolapse, desire for non-surgical management in mild to moderate cases.
  • ↳ Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension Significant prolapse, symptomatic, desire for definitive surgical correction
  • ↳ Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension
  • ↳ Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension
  • ↳ Significant prolapse, symptomatic, desire for definitive surgical correction
  • ↳ Significant prolapse, symptomatic, desire for definitive surgical correction
  • ↳ McCall culdoplasty (Option D) Significant posterior vaginal wall prolapse, desire for surgical repair in which preservation of the uterus is desired.
  • ↳ McCall culdoplasty (Option D)
  • ↳ McCall culdoplasty (Option D)
  • ↳ (Option D)
  • ↳ Significant posterior vaginal wall prolapse, desire for surgical repair in which preservation of the uterus is desired.
  • ↳ Significant posterior vaginal wall prolapse, desire for surgical repair in which preservation of the uterus is desired.
  • ↳ Sacrocolpopexy Severe prolapse, previous failed repairs, desire for durable support
  • ↳ Sacrocolpopexy
  • ↳ Sacrocolpopexy
  • ↳ Severe prolapse, previous failed repairs, desire for durable support
  • ↳ Severe prolapse, previous failed repairs, desire for durable support
  • ↳ Colpocleisis Elderly or frail patients, desire for definitive closure of the vagina
  • ↳ Colpocleisis
  • ↳ Colpocleisis
  • ↳ Elderly or frail patients, desire for definitive closure of the vagina
  • ↳ Elderly or frail patients, desire for definitive closure of the vagina

Treatment Option

Indications

Conservative (pelvic floor exercises) (Option A)

Mild prolapse, asymptomatic, patient preference

Pessary fitting (Option B)

Symptomatic prolapse, desire for non-surgical management in mild to moderate cases.

Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension

Significant prolapse, symptomatic, desire for definitive surgical correction

McCall culdoplasty (Option D)

Significant posterior vaginal wall prolapse, desire for surgical repair in which preservation of the uterus is desired.

Sacrocolpopexy

Severe prolapse, previous failed repairs, desire for durable support

Colpocleisis

Elderly or frail patients, desire for definitive closure of the vagina

questions.text: Identify the following and its usage in obstetrics and gynecology.

options.label: A
options.text: Device used to monitor fetal heart rate during labour

options.label: B
options.text: Contraceptive device inserted into the uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Support device used to manage pelvic organ prolapse

options.label: D
options.text: Tool for inducing labour contractions during childbirth

questions.correct_answer: C. Support device used to manage pelvic organ prolapse
questions.explanation:
Shape

Circular or ring-shaped, with a central opening.

Insertion

Into the vagina.

Indications

Used for pelvic organ prolapse or urinary incontinence.

Contraindications
  • Active infections (PID, vaginitis)
  • Latex sensitivity
  • Noncompliant patient

Complications

Vaginal irritation/discomfort.

questions.text: A 45-year-old multiparous woman presents with a feeling of heaviness and something coming out of her vagina. She also has occasional lower back pain. On examination, there is a visible protrusion of a mass in the vaginal canal. Which of the following is the common complication associated with the condition?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

Urinary incontinence (M/C)

Loss of bladder control (stress incontinence).

Urinary retention

Difficulty in bladder emptying

Recurrent urinary infections

Due to incomplete bladder emptying.

Bowel Dysfunction

Constipation, straining, and faecal incontinence.

Vaginal Ulceration

Due to exposure and friction.

Sexual Dysfunction

Pain or discomfort during intercourse.

Pelvic Pain

Chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia

questions.text: A 54-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with urinary incontinence and heaviness in the pelvic area. Physical examination revealed a noticeable bulge protruding from her vagina. She has a history of uncontrolled diabetes and severe cardiovascular disease. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.explanation:
Indications of Pessary use in prolapse:
  • Early pregnancy up to 18 weeks
  • Puerperium (facilitate involution)
  • Unfit for surgical repair (old female with multiple co-morbidities)
  • While waiting for surgical management.

Complications of Pessary:
  • Pessary ulcers: treated by local estrogen
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Pelvic pain (with the use of larger pessaries)
  • Vaginal discharge

questions.text: In which of the following patients would Le Fort's repair be indicated?

options.label: A
options.text: Partial prolapse in a 35-year-old pregnant female

options.label: B
options.text: Complete prolapse in a 60-year-old female who has completed her family

options.label: C
options.text: Complete prolapse in a 65-year-old female with pelvic inflammatory disease

options.label: D
options.text: Complete prolapse in a 62-year-old female with a history of cervical cancer

questions.correct_answer: B. Complete prolapse in a 60-year-old female who has completed her family

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who underwent a Fothergill repair for uterine prolapse five years ago presents with a history of recurrent second-trimester miscarriages. What is the most likely complication associated with her previous surgical procedure?
questions.explanation:
Indication:

Preservation of reproductive function in patients with uterine prolapse

Steps:
  1. Dilatation and curettage.
  2. Amputation of the cervix.
  3. Plication of the Mackenrodt’s (cardinal) ligaments.
  4. Anterior colporrhaphy and colpoperineorrhaphy.

Complications:
  • Cervical stenosis
  • Fibrosis
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Urinary retention

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with complaints of vaginal bulge and increased pelvic pressure. On pelvic examination, the cervix is visible at the introitus. The patient desires for future childbearing. What is the management of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Anterior sling surgery

Posterior sling surgery
  • Purandare sling
  • Dynamic sling
  • One side: isthmus of the uterus
  • Other side: rectus sheath
  • Low success rate
  • Fewer complications
  • Shirodkar sling
  • Static sling
  • One side: isthmus of the uterus
  • Other side: Ligaments attached to the sacral promontory
  • More complications:
    • Intestinal obstruction (sigmoid colon)
    • Genitofemoral nerve injury
    • Mesenteric injury

Category

Treatment

Nulliparous or congenital prolapse

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation

Pregnancy & postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks POG)
  • Pelvic floor exercises

<40 Years
  • Fothergill’s repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar’s procedure

>40 Years - with completed family

Vaginal hysterectomy & pelvic floor repair

>60 Years - unit for surgery
  • Le-fort’s repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn’t want to retain sexual function

questions.text: Which of the following structures comprise DeLancey’s level 2 support?
questions.explanation:
Structures

Level I
  • Uterosacral ligaments
  • Cardinal ligaments

Level II
  • Arcus tendineus fascia
  • Pubocervical fascia
  • Rectovaginal fascia and septum

Level III
  • Perineal body
  • Superficial and deep perineal muscles
  • Fibromuscular connective tissue

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with lower back pain and constipation for the last few weeks. Rectovaginal examination reveals a bulge felt in the posterior vaginal wall & felt on tip of the finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old woman presents with urinary incontinence and pelvic discomfort for last several weeks. She has to manually reposition the bulge to pass urine each time. There is no uterocervical descent.Which of the following is most suitable for surgical management for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Pelvic discomfort
  • Anterior vaginal wall prolapse
  • Bulge shows transverse rugosities and impulse on coughing

Management

Surgical: (recommended for women >40 years)

  • Anterior Colporrhaphy: (most preferred)
    • weakened tissue between the bladder and vagina is repaired.
  • Mesh Repair: (Option B)
    • synthetic mesh is used for additional support.
    • Risk of recurrence, mesh erosion and infection
  • Sacral Colpopexy: (Option C)
    • Mesh is attached from the top of the vagina to the sacrum to lift the prolapsed organs.
    • High risk of recurrence and complications
  • Vaginal Hysterectomy: (Option D)
    • Considered in cases where uterine prolapse coexists with cystocele.

Conservative:

  • Recommended in young women with prolapse following childbirth for initial 4-6 months
  • Pelvic Floor Exercises
  • Lifestyle modifications: avoid heavy lifting and constipation
  • Pessary insertion (in patients unfit for surgery)

questions.text: Which term describes the elongation of the supravaginal portion of the cervix?
On examination of a 60-year-old female with prolapse, the leading edge is more than 1 cm above the level of the hymen. Which stage of the POP-Q system does this finding correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Stage 0

(Option A)

No prolapse.

Stage I (Option B)

The leading edge (most distal portion) of prolapse is more than 1 cm above the level of the hymen.

Stage II

(Option C)

The leading edge of prolapse is ≤1 cm proximal or distal to the hymen.

Stage III

(Option B)

The leading edge of the prolapse is more than 1 cm below the hymen but ≤ 2 cm less than the total vaginal length.

Stage IV

Essentially complete eversion of the total vaginal length.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classification system used for uterine prolapse?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Shaw Classification uses introitus as the reference point
  • ↳ Shaw Classification
  • ↳ introitus
  • ↳ Rest all classifications including BADEN WALKER & Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification ( POP-Q ) - use hymen as the reference point
  • ↳ BADEN WALKER &
  • ↳ POP-Q
  • ↳ hymen

Grade

Degree of descent

0

Normal position for each respective site

1

Descent halfway to the hymen

2

Descent to the hymen

3

Descent halfway past the hymen

4

Maximum possible descent for each site

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a bulge in her vaginal area that worsens with standing for prolonged periods or straining. She has to push the bulge back into her vagina manually to relieve discomfort. Examination shows the following finding, uterine fundus lying outside the introitus with complete eversion of vaginal walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
First degree

The uterus descends downward, but the external os (opening of the cervix) remains inside the vagina.

Second degree

The uterine body remains inside the vagina while the external os protrudes outside the vaginal introitus.

Third degree 

The cervix, uterine body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus.

The complete uterus protrudes outside the vagina.
Procidentia Prolapse of the uterus with complete eversion of the vagina.

questions.text: Match the following terms with their correct definitions. 1 Cystocele i The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall 2 Urethrocele ii The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall 3 Enterocele iii Laxity of the middle 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall 4 Rectocele iv The collapse of the lower 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall
questions.explanation:
Cystocele

The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall

Urethrocele

The collapse of the lower 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall

Enterocele

The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall

Rectocele

Laxity of the middle 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall and rectovaginal septum

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the role of uterosacral and cardinal ligaments in preventing prolapse?

options.label: A
options.text: They anchor the midvagina to pelvic structures, supporting the anterior and posterior vagina against downward pressures.

options.label: B
options.text: They support the lower part of the vagina and introitus, maintaining perineal muscle structure to prevent specific types of prolapse.

options.label: C
options.text: They suspend the upper vagina, maintain its length and position, and keep the cervix above specific pelvic landmarks, preventing various types of prolapse.

options.label: D
options.text: They connect the perineal body to muscles, helping to maintain the integrity of the anterior vaginal wall and urethra to prevent prolapse.

questions.correct_answer: C. They suspend the upper vagina, maintain its length and position, and keep the cervix above specific pelvic landmarks, preventing various types of prolapse.
questions.explanation:
Function

Damage Results

Level I
  • Suspends upper vagina
  • Maintains vaginal length and horizontal axis
  • Positions cervix above ischial spines
  • Uterine descent
  • Enterocele
  • Vault descent

Level II
  • Attaches midvagina to arcus tendineus fascia pelvis (Option A)
  • Provides lateral and apical anchor sites for anterior and posterior vagina
  • Withstands downward pressures against the anterior vaginal wall and urethra
  • Cystocele
  • Rectocele

Level III
  • Supports distal one-third of the vagina and introitus (Options B & D)
  • Urethrocele
  • Gaping introitus
  • Deficient perineum

questions.text: Which of the following factors primarily causes uterine prolapse by directly damaging the pelvic support structures?
questions.explanation:
Predisposing Factors

Aggravating Factors

Other Factors
  • Prolonged vaginal delivery (prolonged labour).
  • Big baby.
  • Menopause.
  • Congenital weakness (Marfan’s syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome).
  • Raised intra-abdominal pressure (e.g. COPD, constipation, obesity, etc).
  • Increasing age.
  • Multiparity.
  • Smoking (Option D).
  • Pelvic trauma.
    • Perineal tear.
    • Pudendal nerve injury.
  • Spina bifida.
